title: Patriots star Christian Gonzalez has a big fan in Bruins legend Zdeno Chara
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots cornerback Christian Gonzalez honors Boston by wearing custom t-shirts featuring local sports legends during pregame warmups.
Gonzalez's tribute to Zdeno Chara included wearing a t-shirt just before Chara's number was retired by the Bruins.
Chara praised Gonzalez's performance and gesture amid New England's playoff and Super Bowl campaign.

title: Inside the origin of the Patriots’ ‘road warriors’ rallying cry
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The New England Patriots are undefeated in road games this season with a 9-0 record away from Gillette Stadium.
The team chose to wear their road white uniforms for Super Bowl LX, embracing their 'road warriors' identity.
Coach Mike Vrabel introduced the 'road warriors' mantra, inspired by 80s wrestling and the film 'The Warriors'.

title: Did you follow the local news this week? Take our Greater Boston news quiz.
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Boston.com offers a quiz to test knowledge on recent Greater Boston news stories.
Peter Chianca, Boston.com's general assignment editor since 2019, oversees the quiz content.
The quiz aims to keep readers informed about trending issues in the Greater Boston area.

title: Legendary Patriots kicker Adam Vinatieri elected to Pro Football Hall of Fame
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Adam Vinatieri, NFL's all-time scoring leader, has been elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame.
Vinatieri is recognized for crucial Super Bowl kicks and played 24 seasons with Patriots and Colts.
Other 2026 Hall of Fame inductees include Luke Kuechly, Larry Fitzgerald, Drew Brees, and Roger Craig.

title: Drake Maye loses MVP award to Matthew Stafford by razor-thin margin
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Drake Maye finished second in NFL MVP voting with 361 points, one vote behind Matthew Stafford who had 366 points.
Maye excelled in 2025, leading the Patriots to a 14-3 record and the Super Bowl after a four-win season.
Maye led the NFL in completion percentage and QBR, while Stafford led in passing yards and touchdowns.

title: Mike Vrabel named 2025 NFL Coach of the Year
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Mike Vrabel named 2025 NFL Coach of the Year, leading New England Patriots to Super Bowl LX.
Vrabel previously won NFL Coach of the Year in 2021 with the Tennessee Titans.
Under Vrabel, the Patriots transformed with a 17-3 season after back-to-back four-win seasons.

title: Unlike Tom Brady, Tedy Bruschi has a dog in the Patriots-Seahawks fight
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Tedy Bruschi expressed strong support for the Patriots in the Super Bowl LX against the Seahawks, unlike Tom Brady's neutral stance.
Bruschi's support for the Patriots is partly due to his friendship with coach Mike Vrabel, his former teammate.
Bruschi praised the Patriots' postseason performance, noting their strong defense and drawing parallels to the 2001 championship team.

title: Pedestrian struck by police cruiser at UMass Lowell, officials say
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: A pedestrian was struck by a police cruiser near Broadway and Wilder Street at UMass Lowell South Campus.
Lowell police and Massachusetts State Police are investigating the crash that occurred around 6:30 p.m.
UMass Lowell described the incident as 'tragic' and will offer counseling to affected community members.

title: New Bedford police investigate after man goes missing, drowns in harbor
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Jason Vasquez, 51, of New Bedford was found drowned in New Bedford Harbor on January 31, 2026.
Vasquez was last seen on January 28 after visiting a local adult establishment, reported missing on January 30.
New Bedford police, alongside Massachusetts State Police, are investigating the incident; foul play has not been ruled out.

title: Cambridge brewery workers plan to unionize, file for election
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Lamplighter Brewing Co. workers in Cambridge filed for a union election with UFCW Local 1445, representing regional food industry workers.
The filing affects workers from two locations, 284 Broadway and 110 North First St., with union support emphasizing worker representation.
Lamplighter employees cite the evolving brewery industry as a reason to unionize, seeking consistent workplace voice and perspective.
